questions.question: Which of the following is essential to a balanced diet?
Which of the following four food items is the best source of vitamin C?
Which of the following foods contains carbohydrates?
Under-eating is as bad for your health as overeating.  Why is this?

options.label: a
options.text: Because if you under-eat you may not get sufficient vitamins and minerals

options.label: b
options.text: Because if you under-eat you are always hungry

options.label: c
options.text: Because if you under-eat you look thin

options.label: d
options.text: Because if you under-eat you get too much protein

questions.question: Which of the following health problems is not related to eating too many calories?
What are low density lipoproteins (LDL's)?

options.label: b
options.text: Fat that is stored in the body

options.label: c
options.text: Chemicals that carry carbohydrates in the bloodstream

options.label: d
options.text: Chemicals that carry cholesterol in the bloodstream

questions.question: The level of cholesterol in your body is determined by what?
Which is the best for your heart?

options.label: a
options.text: A high proportion of HDL cholesterol compared to LDL cholesterol

options.label: b
options.text: Equal amounts of HDL cholesterol compared to LDL cholesterol

options.label: c
options.text: A low proportion of HDL cholesterol compared to LDL cholesterol

questions.question: Some people follow special diets to reduce their weight. One of these is called the Atkins diet which is very low in carbohydrates. This forces the body to do what?

options.label: a
options.text: To lose weight by burning its stores of fat

options.label: b
options.text: To lose weight by reducing the amount of protein eaten

options.label: c
options.text: To lose weight by increasing the number of calories eaten

options.label: d
options.text: To lose weight by not digesting food properly

questions.question: The Weight Watchers diet gives points values for all of the food eaten. It does not limit what can be eaten but requires the person to stay to their points limit. Which of the following statements best describes this diet?

options.label: a
options.text: The diet causes weight loss by increasing the amount of vitamins and minerals eaten

options.label: b
options.text: The diet causes weight loss by increasing the amount of protein eaten

options.label: c
options.text: The diet causes weight loss by artificially increasing metabolic rate

options.label: d
options.text: The diet causes weight loss whilst eating a balanced diet

questions.question: Which of the following statements about a balanced diet is not true?

options.label: b
options.text: Proteins are needed for growth and repair

options.label: c
options.text: Vitamins and minerals are needed in large quantities

options.label: d
options.text: Fats can come from both animal and plant sources

questions.question: During exercise, breathing rate and heart rate both increase. Why?

options.label: a
options.text: To deliver more oxygen to your muscles

options.label: b
options.text: Because you are using up the nutrients from your last meal

options.label: c
options.text: To deliver more oxygen to your stomach so that you can release more energy from your food

options.label: d
options.text: Because your blood vessels are bigger

questions.question: How does exercise help your circulation?

options.label: a
options.text: By making you stronger and fitter

options.label: b
options.text: By helping your body control it's metabolic rates

options.label: d
options.text: By increasing levels of HDL cholesterol

questions.question: Why is over exercising bad for you?

options.label: a
options.text: It can strain your heart muscles

options.label: c
options.text: It takes up too much time

options.label: d
options.text: You get too much protein in your blood

questions.question: Which long term health problem is not related to a lack of exercise?
Why do your muscles need to be supplied with more blood during exercise?

options.label: b
options.text: Blood makes them larger so they can do more work

options.label: c
options.text: Muscle cell respiration is greater during exercise

options.label: d
options.text: So that they can get more protein for energy

questions.question: What is the chemical that causes cramp?
After exercise, why do your heart rate and breathing rate stay higher than normal?

options.label: a
options.text: To get rid of lactic acid

options.label: b
options.text: Because it takes a while for your chest and heart muscles to slow down

options.label: c
options.text: Because it takes time for messages to reach your brain to say that you have stopped exercising

options.label: d
options.text: Because your body is staying ready just in case you start exercising again

questions.question: What is metabolic rate?

options.label: c
options.text: The speed of the chemical reactions in your body

options.label: d
options.text: The speed your blood flows through your arteries

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true about your metabolic rate after exercise?

options.label: c
options.text: It stays high for a while and then goes back to normal

options.label: d
options.text: It stays low for a while and then goes back to normal

questions.question: How do bacteria and viruses make you feel ill?

options.label: a
options.text: They both damage the cells in your body

options.label: b
options.text: Bacteria irritate the cells of your body and viruses produce toxins

options.label: c
options.text: They take over the cells in your body

options.label: d
options.text: The waste materials from bacteria are toxic to the body and viruses damage your cells

questions.question: Which of the following can be used to help protect your body from microorganisms?
In many hospital wards it is necessary for you to wash your hands with a special gel before going in or out. Before the middle of the 19th Century, not even doctors washed their hands. Why not?

options.label: a
options.text: They didn't know about microorganisms and how they can cause disease

options.label: c
options.text: Hand cleaning gels for hospitals had not been invented

options.label: d
options.text: Hospitals could not afford to buy soap for them to use

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of passive immunity?

options.label: a
options.text: Mucus and cilia in the respiratory system

questions.question: Robert Koch discovered how to grow bacteria in a laboratory. How did this help medical science?

options.label: a
options.text: It prevented laboratory technicians from catching infectious diseases

options.label: b
options.text: It enabled him to identify some pathogenic microorganisms and linked them to specific  diseases

options.label: c
options.text: It allowed doctors to make their own vaccines for their patients

options.label: d
options.text: It meant that hospitals could now save money on drugs

questions.question: A group of Y11 students carried out an investigation into antibiotics which required them to grow some bacteria cultures. Which one of the following is not something they would have done whilst setting up the cultures?

options.label: a
options.text: Sterilise the Petri dishes and use sterilised agar gel

options.label: b
options.text: Sterilise the wire loops used for sampling in a flame

options.label: c
options.text: Seal the Petri dishes with sellotape

options.label: d
options.text: Pick up the antibiotic discs using their hands

questions.question: Why are bacteria cultures in a school or college laboratory grown at much lower temperatures (25oC compared to 37oC) than in a professional microbiology lab?

options.label: a
options.text: It is less dangerous as the bacteria grow more slowly

options.label: c
options.text: School agar gel melts at temperatures above 25oC

options.label: d
options.text: Schools and colleges can't leave the heaters on all day and all night

questions.question: Vaccination is used to immunise people against diseases. Pick the false statement:

options.label: a
options.text: When a vaccine is injected into the body, it stimulates the white blood cells to produce antibodies against the pathogen

options.label: b
options.text: There are no possible side-effects from any vaccination

options.label: c
options.text: Vaccines can contain the live pathogen that has been specially treated to make it harmless

options.label: d
options.text: Harmless fragments of the pathogen and toxins produced by pathogens can both be used as vaccines

questions.question: Why are antibiotics no good for treating colds and 'flu?

options.label: c
options.text: Colds and 'flu are caused by bacteria that are resistant to antibiotics

questions.question: Which of the following statements is not true?

options.label: a
options.text: Unless it is controlled, HIV attacks the body's immune cells

options.label: b
options.text: HIV can be spread through sexual contact and by drug users who share needles

options.label: d
options.text: The initial effect of HIV is usually a flu-like illness

questions.question: Which of the following statements about white blood cells is incorrect?

options.label: b
options.text: They expel the pathogens from the bloodstream via the liver

options.label: c
options.text: They produce antibodies which neutralise pathogens

options.label: d
options.text: They produce antitoxins to neutralise the effects of the toxins from pathogens

questions.question: Your body can develop a natural immunity to certain pathogens. What is the name of the cells responsible for this?
What is produced by a lymphocyte that enables it to neutralise pathogens?
Which of the following statements is correct?

options.label: b
options.text: Antibiotics work because the prevent the toxins from being poisonous to the host

options.label: c
options.text: White blood cells produce antigens to protect the body

options.label: d
options.text: Viruses cause cholera and typhoid in poor areas of the world

questions.question: Which of the following also help your body defend itself against infection?

options.label: a
options.text: Mucus and cilia in the respiratory system

questions.question: Which of the following is not one of the ways that white blood cells provide active immunity?

options.label: a
options.text: They destroy invading pathogens by eating them

options.label: b
options.text: They produce antibodies to destroy pathogens

options.label: c
options.text: They produce antitoxins that neutralise toxins from pathogens

options.label: d
options.text: They destroy pathogens by ingesting them

questions.question: Which of the following are the two main groups of white blood cells?
The lymphocytes produce antibodies. How do antibodies work?

options.label: a
options.text: They penetrate inside the pathogen and destroy its nucleus

options.label: b
options.text: They penetrate inside the pathogen and change the chemical composition of the cytoplasm

options.label: c
options.text: They attach to the pathogens and cause them to clump together making it easy for phagocytes to find and ingest them

options.label: d
options.text: They attach to the pathogens and take them to the liver where they are destroyed

questions.question: Vaccination is used to immunise people against diseases. Pick the false statement:

options.label: a
options.text: Edward Jenner is credited with the discovery of vaccination

options.label: b
options.text: Vaccines contain the antibodies needed to protect your body from infection

options.label: c
options.text: Each vaccine protects you from a specific disease

options.label: d
options.text: Some vaccines contain the pathogen that causes the disease

questions.question: Why are antibiotics no good for treating colds and 'flu?

options.label: b
options.text: Cold and 'flu mutate too quickly so the antibiotics only work for a very short time

options.label: c
options.text: Colds and 'flu are 'superbugs' and totally resistant to antibiotics

options.label: d
options.text: Antibiotics cannot work fast enough to treat colds and 'flu

options.label: d

questions.question:
What are the missing words in the correct order from this description of a reflex action?

1. A ______ detects a stimulus.
2. A sensory neurone sends impulses to a ______ neurone.
3. A motor _______ sends impulses to an effector.
4. An effector produces a ________.
When you are too hot or too cold, the brain sends nerve messages to the skin to do several things. Which one of the following is not a response used to control body temperature?

options.label: a
options.text: Tiny hairs on the skin can be raised and lowered by small muscles

options.label: b
options.text: Blood vessels in the skin can be dilated or contracted

options.label: c
options.text: Glands in the skin are stimulated to release greater quantities of natural oils onto the surface of the skin

options.label: d
options.text: Glands in the skin are stimulated to release sweat

questions.question: Why is it important to maintain an even temperature of 37oC for the human body?

options.label: a
options.text: It is a nice temperature to be at

options.label: b
options.text: It is an easy temperature to maintain

options.label: c
options.text: When life first started, that was the temperature of the Earth

options.label: d
options.text: The enzymes in the body work most efficiently at that temperature

questions.question: The main method of controlling the amount of water in the body is via the kidneys. How does this happen?

options.label: a
options.text: A hormone is used to send a message to the kidney to excrete more water

options.label: b
options.text: Nerve impulses from the brain are used to send a message to the kidney to excrete more water

options.label: d
options.text: No message is needed, it will happen automatically

questions.question: Choose the pair of words that best describes where hormones are produced and how they are transported.
Which of the following hormones is not involved in human fertility?
In which gland are FSH and LH produced?
The hormone oestrogen is secreted by the ovaries. Which of the following is a function of oestrogen?

options.label: b
options.text: It maintains the lining of the uterus

options.label: c
options.text: It causes the release of an egg from the ovary

options.label: d
options.text: It stops FSH from being produced

questions.question: The hormone progesterone is secreted by the ovaries. Which of the following is a function of progesterone?

options.label: b
options.text: It maintains the lining of the uterus

options.label: c
options.text: It causes the release of an egg from the ovary

options.label: d
options.text: It stops FSH from being produced

questions.question: The oral contraceptive pill greatly reduces the chances of a woman producing mature eggs and therefore reduces her chances of becoming pregnant. Which of the following are possible side effects?

options.label: a
options.text: Changes in weight, mood and blood pressure

questions.question: How do fertility drugs work?

options.label: a
options.text: They contain oestrogen which stimulates egg production in the ovaries

options.label: b
options.text: They contain progesterone which causes lots of eggs to be released from the ovaries

options.label: c
options.text: They contain three hormones which fertilise an egg in the ovaries

options.label: d
options.text: They contain FSH which stimulates eggs to mature in the ovaries

questions.question: When is in vitro fertilisation (IVF) used?

options.label: a
options.text: When a woman is unable to produce her own eggs

options.label: b
options.text: When the lining of the uterus cannot support natural fertilisation

options.label: c
options.text: When the quantity or quality of a man's sperm is poor

options.label: d
options.text: When a couple wants to have twins

questions.question: Why is FSH used during IVF?

options.label: a
options.text: It increases the number of eggs available for fertilisation

options.label: b
options.text: It stimulates the uterus to be ready to receive the fertilised egg

options.label: c
options.text: It prevents the woman's body from producing oestrogen

options.label: d
options.text: It helps the man produce better quality sperm

options.text: Skin darkening in response to sunlight

options.text: Plant leaves losing their green colour when there isn't much sunlight

options.label: a
options.text: Roots growing downwards, shoots growing upwards

options.label: d

questions.question: Which of the following options applies to the plant hormones, auxins?

options.label: a

options.label: c
options.text: Auxins are made in the growing tips and spread  throughout the plant

questions.question: Which of these combinations describes the tropisms of shoots correctly?
Which of these combinations describes the tropisms of roots correctly?
What are the three main external stimuli to which plants respond?
The ripening of fruit is a response to hormones. Certain hormones can be sprayed on plants to make the fruit all ripen at the same time. Which of the following is not a disadvantage with this?

options.label: a
options.text: There will be too much to pick all at once

options.label: b
options.text: It is easier for commercial fruit growing companies to pick fruit in one go

options.label: c
options.text: The fruits ripened in this way do not all have the same colour

options.label: d
options.text: The fruits will continue to ripen after they have ben picked

questions.question: If a plant pot with a seedling is placed on its side with a bright light at 45 degrees to the pot and higher, what will happen?

options.label: a
options.text: The whole plant will continue to grow horizontally but the leaves will be at 45 degrees to the stem

options.label: b
options.text: The stem will grow downwards and the roots will continue to grow horizontally

options.label: c
options.text: The stem will grow upwards at 90 degrees and the roots will continue to grow horizontally

options.label: d
options.text: The stem will grow upwards at about 45 degrees and the roots will grow downwards

questions.question: What happens in a plant shoot that makes it grow towards the light?

options.label: a
options.text: The warmth of the light attracts the hormone auxin so the shoot bends in the direction of the light

options.label: b
options.text: The auxin on the lit side of the plant shoot is destroyed by the light, making that side grow less than the other

options.label: c
options.text: There is less auxin on the shaded part of the plant shoot so that side grows more

options.label: d
options.text: The cells on the light side of the shoot shrivel up so that side gets shorter and the shoot bends over towards the light

questions.question: Some students did an experiment on plant shoots. They cut off the tips of the shoots on 10 seedlings, covered the tips of 10 more with kitchen foil and left 10 seedlings as they were as a control. The seedlings were then placed in a large box with a hole cut in one side. Which of the following would describe their results?

options.label: b
options.text: The seedlings that had their tips covered with kitchen foil died; the others grew normally

options.label: c
options.text: The seedlings that had their tips cut off stayed the same; the ones covered in kitchen foil bent away from the hole in the side of the box and the other seedlings grew normally.

options.label: d
options.text: The seedlings that had their tips cut off stayed the same; the ones covered in kitchen foil grew taller than the others and stayed straight; the other seedlings grew towards the hole in the side of the box

questions.question: Which one of the following is not a medical drug?
Why must medical drugs be tested before they are used on patients?

options.label: b
options.text: To check that they are safe to use

questions.question: Why was thalidomide sold to pregnant women?
What were the effects of thalidomide on a foetus?

options.label: d
options.text: Uneven growth of the head bones (elephantitis)

questions.question: What is the importance of thalidomide?

options.label: a
options.text: It was the first ever antibiotic

options.label: b
options.text: It prompted drug testing laws to be improved

options.label: c
options.text: It was the most profitable drug of all time

options.label: d
options.text: It was the first drug to be sold that didn't need a prescription

questions.question: Why are drugs tested on cells, tissues and live animals in the laboratory first?

options.label: a
options.text: Only to see if it does what the scientists hope it will do

options.label: b
options.text: Only to find out if it could be toxic

options.label: c
options.text: Only to check for the right dose

options.label: d
options.text: To see if it if it works and is non-toxic

questions.question: What is the purpose of the first clinical trial?

options.label: a
options.text: To see if it is toxic to humans

options.label: c
options.text: To make some money so that they can manufacture the drug

options.label: d
options.text: To see if people like the taste of the new drug

questions.question: What is a placebo?

options.label: a
options.text: A double strength version of a drug

options.label: b
options.text: A half strength version of a drug

options.label: c
options.text: A fake version of the drug

options.label: d
options.text: A scientist who specialises in doing clinical trials

questions.question: What is a double blind clinical trial?

options.label: a
options.text: One in which the patients wear blindfolds so they don't know if they have had the drug or the placebo

options.label: b
options.text: Only the doctors know who has had the drug and who has had the placebo

options.label: c
options.text: Only the patients know who has had the drug and who has had the placebo

options.label: d
options.text: Neither the doctors nor the patients know who has had the drug and who has had the placebo until afterwards

questions.question: Which of these is one reason why it costs a lot of money to develop new drugs?

options.label: a
options.text: A lot of the new substances being developed as drugs fail the first tests

options.label: b
options.text: It makes the drugs companies more profit

options.label: c
options.text: They pay large sums of money to people who agree to take part in clinical trials

options.label: d
options.text: Making the placebo costs twice as much as making the new drug

questions.question: Which one of the following is not a medical drug?
Why must medical drugs be tested before they are used on patients?

options.label: b
options.text: To check that they are safe to use

questions.question: Why was thalidomide sold to pregnant women?
What were the effects of thalidomide on a foetus?

options.label: d
options.text: Uneven growth of the head bones (elephantitis)

questions.question: What is the importance of thalidomide?

options.label: a
options.text: It was the first ever antibiotic

options.label: b
options.text: It prompted drug testing laws to be improved

options.label: c
options.text: It was the most profitable drug of all time

options.label: d
options.text: It was the first drug to be sold that didn't need a prescription

questions.question: Why are drugs tested on cells, tissues and live animals in the laboratory first?

options.label: a
options.text: Only to see if it does what the scientists hope it will do

options.label: b
options.text: Only to find out if it could be toxic

options.label: c
options.text: Only to check for the right dose

options.label: d
options.text: To see if it if it works and is non-toxic

questions.question: What is the purpose of the first clinical trial?

options.label: a
options.text: To see if it is toxic to humans

options.label: c
options.text: To make some money so that they can manufacture the drug

options.label: d
options.text: To see if people like the taste of the new drug

questions.question: What is a placebo?

options.label: a
options.text: A double strength version of a drug

options.label: b
options.text: A half strength version of a drug

options.label: c
options.text: A fake version of the drug

options.label: d
options.text: A scientist who specialises in doing clinical trials

questions.question: What is a double blind clinical trial?

options.label: a
options.text: One in which the patients wear blindfolds so they don't know if they have had the drug or the placebo

options.label: b
options.text: Only the doctors know who has had the drug and who has had the placebo

options.label: c
options.text: Only the patients know who has had the drug and who has had the placebo

questions.question: A drug is a substance that always ...

options.label: a
options.text: has no effect on the body

options.label: b
options.text: changes the chemical processes in the body

questions.question: Drugs that are classed as stimulants ...

options.label: d
options.text: increase your heart rate and other bodily processes

questions.question: Alcohol and tobacco are examples of what type of drugs?
Regular drinkers of alcoholic drinks can become addicted to them. Which of the following is the addictive substance in alcoholic drinks?
Which of the following are long term effects of regular misuse of alcohol on the human body?
The legal recreational drug nicotine is usually obtained from smoking tobacco. Which of the following statements is not  true?

options.label: a
options.text: Smoking increases your risk of lung, mouth and throat cancer

options.label: b
options.text: Nicotine is addictive making it hard for regular smokers to stop smoking

options.label: c
options.text: It takes several hours for the nicotine in cigarette smoke to reach the brain

options.label: d
options.text: The circulatory system is damaged by smoking, which increases the risk of heart disease and strokes

questions.question: Which of the following statements about cannabis is true?

options.label: a
options.text: Long-term use of cannabis can damage your brain and cause mental illness in some people

options.label: b
options.text: Smoking cannabis does no harm to your body

options.label: c
options.text: Long-term use of cannabis causes your eyesight to deteriorate

options.label: d
options.text: Cannabis helps you to concentrate better

questions.question: Doctors say that pregnant women should not drink alcohol or smoke tobacco or cannabis. Why?

options.label: a
options.text: They think the mother should be saving her money to spend on the baby

options.label: b
options.text: It increases the risk of miscarriage, premature birth, reduced intelligence of the baby and low birth weight

options.label: c
options.text: The baby will be born with a strange coloured skin

questions.question: Some people take energy drinks that contain caffeine to increase their sports performance. Caffeine is a stimulant drug, this means that it ...

options.label: a
options.text: increases the number of red cells in the blood so it can carry more oxygen to the muscles

options.label: b
options.text: increases the number of white cells in the blood so it can carry more oxygen to the muscles

options.label: c
options.text: increases blood pressure and heart rate which gets more oxygen to the muscles in a shorter time

options.label: d
options.text: increases muscle mass making them stronger and faster

options.label: c
options.text: Animals - food and spacePlants - water and space

options.label: d
options.text: Animals - food, water and spacePlants - water and space

questions.question: The Forestry Commission have planted lots of trees in Scotland, often in quite wet and boggy countryside. These trees are mainly Sitka spruce, which are evergreen and are planted close together. Which of the following might explain why there are not many plants growing on the forest floor?

options.label: a
options.text: Very little sunlight can get though all year round

options.label: b
options.text: The trees take up all the water

options.label: c
options.text: The other plants were destroyed when the land was ploughed to plant the trees

options.label: d
options.text: The tree roots get in the way

questions.question: What happens to plants and animals that are unsuccessful in competing for resources?

options.label: a
options.text: The other plants and animals help them

options.label: c
options.text: They die or move to another place

questions.question: Lions live in groups (prides). The dominant male lions sometimes chase some of the male cubs away as they approach sexual maturity, making them leave the pride. Why do you think this is?

options.label: a
options.text: Less competition for mates in the future

options.label: b
options.text: Less competition for water in the future

options.label: c
options.text: Less competition for space in the future

options.label: d
options.text: The cubs are not cute any more

options.label: d
options.text: they grew taller at first and after a week they didn't grow much more

questions.question: Ladybirds feed on insects called aphids. What happens when the number of aphids increases?
When the grey squirrel was introduced to parks in Britain in the 1870s, the numbers of the native red squirrels decreased. Why?

options.label: a
options.text: The two types of squirrel mated and their offspring were always grey because red fur is a recessive gene

options.label: b
options.text: Grey squirrels are more successful at competing for water

options.label: c
options.text: The people who introduced grey squirrels didn't like red squirrels and killed them

options.label: d
options.text: The grey squirrel is more successful in competing for food

questions.question: In North America, the lynx is an animal that feeds on hares. Which of the following features of the hare will not help it run away before a lynx can get close enough to catch it.

options.label: c
options.text: Eyes on the side of the head

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the population curve for a predator-prey relationship?

options.label: a
options.text: Predator numbers decline some time after prey numbers drop

options.label: b
options.text: Predator numbers decline some time before prey numbers drop

options.label: c
options.text: Predator numbers decline at exactly the same time as prey numbers drop

options.label: d
options.text: Predator numbers are always higher than prey numbers

Plants compete for ...

questions.question: For which of the following do animals not compete?
Organisms that are tolerant of high levels of salt, high temperatures or high pressures are called what?
The jackrabbit is an animal that lives in the desert. One of its adaptations is that it has much larger ears than rabbits living in Britain. Which of the following is the least likely to be true?

options.label: a
options.text: Bigger ears can help it to hear predators coming

options.label: b
options.text: Hot air muffles sound so it needs bigger ears to hear

options.label: c
options.text: It can lose heat from its ears instead of sweating

options.label: d
options.text: Big ears are more attractive during the mating season

questions.question: What is the most likely reason from the answers below to explain why roses have thorns?

options.label: a
options.text: The thorns grip on walls to keep the rose plants from falling over

options.label: b
options.text: The thorns are there to stop animals from eating the rose plant

options.label: c
options.text: They grow thorns because they help form the flowers

questions.question: Why do polar bears have white fur?

options.label: a
options.text: To keep them warm when they lie on the ice

options.label: b
options.text: To absorb infra-red radiation from the Sun

options.label: d
options.text: It is camoflage to stop their prey spotting them

questions.question: Some tribes of the Amazon rainforest obtain a poison for their hunting arrows from certain brightly coloured frogs. Why are these frogs brightly coloured?

options.label: b
options.text: It makes their skin completely waterproof

options.label: c
options.text: The poison in the frogs makes their skin turn brightly coloured

questions.question: How much of the Sun's energy produces biomass in plants?

In one year, the Sun supplies 4 x 106kJ to a particular habitat, 15kJ reaches the top predator. What percentage of the Sun's energy is transferred to the predator? Try working it out rather than trying to guess.

Students investigated a food chain in a garden. The students found 650 aphids feeding on one rose plant. Five ladybirds were feeding on the aphids. Which of the following statements about the biomass of the ladybirds is true?

options.label: a
options.text: The biomass of the ladybirds is greater than the biomass of the aphids

options.label: b
options.text: The biomass of the ladybirds is less than the biomass of the rose plant

options.label: c
options.text: The biomass of the ladybirds is more than the biomass of the rose plant

options.label: d
options.text: The biomass of the ladybirds is the same as the biomass of the aphids

questions.question: Students measured the biomass of a community living in leaf litter under the trees in the school conservation area. They found woodlice feeding on the leaves, ground beetles feeding on the woodlice and centipedes feeding on the beetles. Each student weighed the leaves in their sample and the other organisms and put their results together with the rest of the class. Which of the following could represent the class results in order of the food chain starting from the leaves?
For every 200kJ a gazelle gets from eating, 125kJ are excreted and 65kJ are used in respiration so how much of the original energy would be passed on to a lion that caught and ate it?

questions.question: In what form can these materials be returned to the environment?
How does nature recycle dead and waste materials?
Which of the following makes things decay?
How do microorganisms cause decay?

options.label: a
options.text: They release enzymes which break down the dead material

options.label: b
options.text: They release hormones that break down the dead material

options.label: c
options.text: They engulf the dead material piece by piece

options.label: d
options.text: They use their vacuoles as miniature mouths

questions.question: Some students carried out an experiment to investigate the rate of decay of a potato. Below are just four of the experiments they tried. In which one would the potato decay fastest?

options.label: a
options.text: Large pieces in a dry sealed container in warm conditions

options.label: b
options.text: Small pieces in an open container in warm conditions and sprayed with water each day

options.label: c
options.text: Large pieces in a dry sealed container in a refrigerator

options.label: d
options.text: Small pieces in a dry sealed container in a refrigerator

questions.question: Which word correctly describes something that can be broken down by the microorganisms that cause decay?
Which of the following methods of packaging does not break down naturally?

options.label: b
options.text: A large envelope made from card

options.label: c
options.text: Tissue paper used to protect delicate items in a box

questions.question: Many local authorities run garden waste composting schemes. Which of the following is not an advantage of this?

options.label: a
options.text: Large branches of trees in the waste need to be cut into much smaller pieces

options.label: b
options.text: It reduces the amount of waste sent to landfill sites

options.label: c
options.text: It recycles nutrients that would otherwise be lost

options.label: d
options.text: The compost can be sold cheaply to local gardeners

questions.question: Gardeners will 'turn' their compost regularly. This involves using a garden fork to bring the compost from the bottom of the pile to the top. Which of the following is the scientific reason for doing this?

options.label: a
options.text: They were taught to do it by their parents

options.label: b
options.text: So that the worms in the compost can get more light

options.label: c
options.text: To get more air into the compost

options.label: d
options.text: Organic materials decay better in the dark

questions.question: What process takes carbon dioxide from the air and makes it available to land living animals?

options.label: b

questions.question: Which of the following is a problem caused by humans burning fossil fuels?

options.label: a
options.text: A hole in the ozone layer

questions.question: How might burning fossil fuels be creating global warming?

options.label: a
options.text: Because fossil fuels will be all used up in a few decades

options.label: b
options.text: Because burning fossil fuels is a very dangerous process

options.label: c
options.text: Because fossil fuels are not compatible with the new biofuels

options.label: d

questions.question: How is carbon in plants passed on to the rest of the cycle?

options.text: Grinding them up into small particles to use for making roads

options.label: d
options.text: When they are subducted during plate tectonics

Which of the following is correct in order of decreasing size?

Why is plotting a line graph of foot length more appropriate than using a bar chart?

options.label: a
options.text: Foot length is an example of continuous variation

options.label: c
options.text: Foot length is an example of discontinuous variation

options.label: d
options.text: Shoe size depends on foot length

questions.question: Which of the following options best describes sexual reproduction?

options.label: a
options.text: The joining of male and female gametes

options.label: b
options.text: The separation of male and female gametes

options.text: The formation of male and female gametes

options.label: d
options.text: Nothing to do with male and female gametes

questions.question: What do we call the cell formed when fertilisation has occurred?

What do we call the process in which a zygote is created artificially by scientists or doctors?

options.label: a
options.text: A zygote is formed during the process of fertilisation

options.label: b
options.text: All plants reproduce by either sexual or asexual reproduction

options.label: c
options.text: Reproduction in a plant results in the formation of a new plant

options.label: d
options.text: In sexual reproduction, the offspring of a plant is identical to one of the parents only

questions.question: How does sexual reproduction lead to evolution?

options.label: b
options.text: It mixes the genes from the two parents

options.label: c
options.text: It creates a completely new set of genes

options.label: a
options.text: In genes that are found in the cytoplasm of a cell

options.label: b
options.text: In genes carried by chromosomes in the nucleus

options.label: c
options.text: In chromosomes carried on the genes of the gametes

options.label: a
options.text: Making a batch of new plants that show variation

options.label: b
options.text: Making new animals that have characteristics different to the parents

questions.question: Which of the following is not true about plant tissue culture?

options.label: a
options.text: It is used to produce plants in sterile conditions, reducing the chances of transmitting diseases and pests

options.label: b
options.text: It is used to produce plants whose seeds have a low chance of germinating

options.label: c
options.text: It is used to create new varieties of flowering plants

options.label: d
options.text: It is used to produce exact copies of plants that produce particularly good flowers or fruits

questions.question: Why does asexual reproduction produce genetically identical offspring?

options.label: a
options.text: Because there is no fusion of gamete

options.label: b
options.text: Because two identical gametes are fused

options.label: d
options.text: Because it is another term for genetic engineering

questions.question: As well as leaves, spider plants grow long branches with lots of plantlets (miniature spider plants) attached. What is the name of this form of asexual reproduction?
During tissue culture, why are plant cells washed in antiseptic before placing them into the culture medium?

options.label: a
options.text: To ensure that no microorganisms grow on the culture medium and new plants

options.label: b
options.text: To destroy any unwanted plant cells, leaving only the cells for cloning

options.label: c
options.text: To prevent viruses from getting into the plant cells

options.label: d
options.text: In case any of the plant cells have cuts or bruises on them

questions.question: Why are plants easier to clone than animals?

options.label: c
options.text: Plant cells can differentiate into different cell types

options.label: d
options.text: They contain chlorophyll which is a good cloning medium

questions.question: When cloning animals from adult cells, which part of the cells is involved?
When cloning animals from adult cells, what must one do to the egg cell to make it start to grow?

options.label: a
options.text: Give it a small electric shock

options.label: b
options.text: Nothing, it will start growing of its own accord

questions.question: When cloning mammals from adult cells, after the nucleus has been replaced and growth has started, where must the egg cell be placed so the clone can develop?

options.label: a
options.text: In a test tube with a suitable 'in vitro' solution

options.label: b
options.text: On agar in a Petri dish

options.label: c
options.text: In the uterus of an adult female of the same type of animal

options.label: d
options.text: In the uterus of an adult female of a different type of animal

questions.question: Another way of cloning animals is by carrying out an embryo transplant. The growing cells of the embryo taken from a pregnant animal can be separated and grown as genetically similar individuals. But at what stage can this be done?

options.label: a
options.text: When the embryo is nearly fully developed

options.label: b
options.text: When the embryo is half way through its development

options.label: c
options.text: When the embryo is growing but before the cells have become specialised

options.label: d
options.text: Immediately after fertilisation of the egg

questions.question: Mutations are changes to an organism's what?
Taking the pollen from one rose flower and using it to pollinate a flower on a different rose plant is an example of what?
Which of the following is not a disadvantage of selective breeding?

options.label: a
options.text: The long term health issues are unknown

options.label: c
options.text: Disease could spread quickly through a population

options.label: d
options.text: There could be an increase in genetic diseases

questions.question: How do scientists cut out a specific gene ready to place into another organism?

options.label: a
options.text: They use a scalpel and a microscope

options.label: b
options.text: They use a small pice of thin glass

options.label: d
options.text: They use a hot wire to cut the DNA in the right place

questions.question:
What is the correct order of these steps which describe genetic modification?
1. Isolation of the gene responsible for the characteristic.
2. Replication of the transgenic organism.
3. Selection of the desired characteristic.
4. Insertion of the gene into another organism.
Where in a cell are the genes found?

options.label: b
options.text: They make up the cell wall

options.label: c
options.text: They are floating around in the cytoplasm

options.label: d
options.text: They are contained in the cell membrane

questions.question: These statements are about the role of enzymes in genetic modification. Which is correct?

options.label: a
options.text: Ligase enzymes are used to cut DNA in specific places

options.label: b
options.text: Restriction enymes are used to cut DNA in specific places

options.label: d
options.text: None of the statements are correct

questions.question: Which of the following can be used as vectors?

Nowadays, most insulin is made using genetically modified bacteria that have had the human gene for insulin inserted into them. Which of the following could be regarded as an advantage of GM insulin over natural insulin?

options.label: a
options.text: It can be made in very large amounts from gentically modified bacteria

options.label: b
options.text: It is less likely to cause an adverse reaction

options.label: c
options.text: It overcomes ethical concerns from vegetarians, vegans and some religious groups

questions.question: Which of the following is a moral objection to genetic engineering of a crop?

options.label: a
options.text: GM food could contain substances that create allergic reactions in some people

options.label: b
options.text: Moving genes from one organism to another is unnatural

options.label: c
options.text: It could cross breed with the same crops in nearby fields, contaminating it in unpredictable ways

options.label: d
options.text: No-one knew how variation and inheritance worked

options.label: a

options.label: b
options.text: Ones which are well adapted to their environment

questions.question: According to Darwin, new species evolve by which process?

options.label: a

options.label: b
options.text: It is based on genetic variation

options.label: c
options.text: It is older than Darwin's and therefore out of date

questions.question: What might happen to an individual that is not well suited to its environment?

options.label: a
options.text: It could die before it has had the chance to reproduce and its genes will not be passed on

options.label: b
options.text: It will be helped by other animals of the same species

options.label: c
options.text: It will learn to be successful and pass on its genes to the next generation

options.label: d
options.text: A hunter will catch and eat it

questions.question: Why is there always variation in any population?

options.label: a
options.text: Half of the genes come from the mother and half from the father

options.label: b
options.text: Genes are all changed during sexual reproduction

options.label: c
options.text: Cosmic radiation damages genes in the sperm and egg cells

questions.question: Darwin's ideas were not well recieved when he published them in 1859. Which of the following is a reason why?

options.label: a
options.text: He was not a trained scientist so other scientists would not believe him

options.label: b
options.text: He had upset the top scientists of the time so they persuaded everyone that his theory was rubbish to get their revenge

options.label: c
options.text: His book was so boring that no-one was able to read it

options.label: d
options.text: His ideas contradicted religious ideas about the Creation

questions.question: The example of  dark peppered moths living in or near to British industrial cities following the Industrial Revolution, whilst light ones live in the countryside, shows what?

options.label: a
options.text: A change in an environment can result in the evolution of species living there

options.label: b
options.text: Evolution occurs so slowly that it is not possible to determine that it has happened in less than a million years

options.label: c
options.text: The environment in or near these cities has always favored dark coloured moths

options.label: d
options.text: There is a better supply of food for dark moths in cities

questions.question: Darwin's theory of evolution by natural selection failed to explain which of the following options?

options.label: a
options.text: There is less variation in a population every generation

options.label: b

options.label: c
options.text: Populations of similar species could live in the same habitat

questions.question: A variation in a plant creates a variety that has seed pods that 'explode' when touched by an animal. How could this lead to natural selection of this characteristic?

options.label: a
options.text: The seeds would be scattered further from the plant

options.label: b
options.text: The animals like the feeling and will brush past the plant more, scattering more seeds

options.label: c
options.text: The seeds fly through the air which activates more of them

options.label: d
options.text: The seeds fly higher and when they hit the ground, they go in further meaning more will grow

questions.question: A student added some nitric acid to a small quantity of powdered calcium carbonate in a large beaker. Which of the following would not have been observed during the experiment?
Which of the following statements about limestone is false?

options.label: a
options.text: It reacts with acid rain and is gradually eroded

options.label: b
options.text: It is used for making the foundations of roads

options.label: c
options.text: It is used in the manufacture of cement

options.label: d
options.text: It is not used in agriculture

questions.question: Calcium carbonate is heated with which of the following substances to make cement?
What is the formula of calcium carbonate?
When calcium carbonate is strongly heated what does it do?
What are the products when calcium carbonate thermally decomposes?
Some students heated pieces of limestone in a roaring flame of a bunsen burner. What would they have observed as the reaction was taking place?

options.label: c
options.text: The limestone expanding at first, then going smaller

options.label: d
options.text: The limestone glowing with an intense white light

questions.question: Heated  limestone was left to cool and when it was cold a few drops of water were added to it. Then a piece of moist litmus paper was touched against it. What was observed?

options.label: a
options.text: The piece of heated limestone hissed, crumbled and became hot. The litmus paper turned red.

options.label: b
options.text: The piece of heated limestone hissed, crumbled and became hot. The litmus paper turned blue.

options.label: c
options.text: The piece of heated limestone turned pale yellow and the litmus paper stayed the same.

options.label: d
options.text: Nothing happened and the litmus paper stayed the same.

options.text: Oxygen is the gas and the solution gives a green precipitate

options.text: Nitrogen is the gas and the solution turns a pale straw colour

options.text: Carbon dioxide is the gas and the solution goes cloudy

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?

options.label: a
options.text: Iron oxide in a blast furnace is oxidised to form iron

options.label: b
options.text: Iron oxide in a blast furnace is electrolysed to form iron

options.label: c
options.text: Iron oxide in a blast furnace is melted to form iron

options.label: d
options.text: Iron oxide in a blast furnace is reduced to form iron

questions.question: What is the main impurity in iron from a blast furnace?
During the process of smelting, what happens to copper ore?
Carbon can be used to remove the oxygen from copper oxide to leave the copper. This contains impurities including carbon. How is this copper purified?

It is said that by the middle of the 21st century economical copper ores will have been used up. New ways of extracting copper from low-grade ores are being researched. One of these is called phytomining. What does phytomining involve?

options.label: a
options.text: Using high powered lasers to blast the copper from the low grade ore

options.label: b
options.text: Using plants to absorb the copper compounds from the ores then burning the plants

options.label: c
options.text: Using the low grade ores with a mixture of chemicals that will dissolve the impurities

options.label: d
options.text: Using radioactive filters to get rid of the impurities

questions.question: Another idea is to dump scrap iron into solutions of copper salts. How would this work?

options.label: a
options.text: The iron would corrode which would push the copper out of solution

options.label: b
options.text: The iron would take any oxygen from the salts leaving behind pure copper

options.label: c
options.text: The iron would displace the copper from the salts

options.label: d
options.text: The iron would be reduced which would cause the copper to be deposited all around the inside of the reaction vessel

questions.question: Bioleaching is yet another idea for getting metals that are less reactive than aluminium from very low grade ores and wastes. What organisms are used in this process?

The most common ore of tin is cassiterite, a form of tin oxide with the formula SnO2. Which of the following is a balanced equation showing the extraction of tin from this ore?
What is an ore?

options.label: a
options.text: Something you use for rowing a boat

options.label: c
options.text: A substance from the ground from which a metal can be economically extracted

questions.question: What is the usual method of extracting a reactive metal from its purified ore?

What is the correct order of these sentences which briefly describe the process used to extract a reactive metal like aluminium?
1. Electrodes are placed into the molten ore.
2. The ore is purified and melted.
3. The molten metal can be tapped off and cast into ingots.
4. The metal ions are deposited as molten aluminium.
Why do the ores of reactive metals need to be molten during the extraction process?

options.label: a
options.text: So that they can be stirred

options.label: b
options.text: So that the metal can be poured off the top

options.label: c
options.text: So that more ore can easily be added when metal is removed

options.label: d
options.text: So that the electricity can pass through the ore

questions.question: During the electrolysis of a reactive metal ore, which electrode attracts the metal ions?
Why can you not obtain group I and group II metals by heating their oxide with carbon?

options.label: a
options.text: Carbon is more reactive than group I and group II metals

options.label: b
options.text: The ores of group I and group II metals are too strong

options.label: c
options.text: The metals are silver in colour but carbon is black

options.label: d
options.text: Carbon is less reactive than the group I and group II metals

questions.question: Titanium is a stronger and lighter metal than iron. Apart from the fact that iron is more abundant in the Earth's crust, why do we not use it instead?

options.label: a
options.text: It is more easily corroded because it is more reactive than iron

options.label: b
options.text: It is only found in countries that like to keep their resources for themselves rather than exporting them

options.label: c
options.text: It is not malleable or ductile

options.label: d
options.text: Extracting it is an expensive and difficult process

questions.question: To extract titanium, the ore (titanium dioxide) is converted to titanium chloride which is then reacted with magnesium at 800oC. The magnesium combines with the chloride, leaving the titanium metal on its own. The reaction of magnesium with the titanium chloride is an example of what sort of reaction?
What does the displacement reaction of magnesium with the titanium chloride tell you about titanium and magnesium?

options.label: c
options.text: Titanium is more reactive than magnesium

options.label: d
options.text: Titanium is less reactive than magnesium

questions.question: Which of the following metals could also be used to displace titanium from its chloride?

questions.question: Which of the following metals could also be used to displace titanium from its chloride?
Which of the following is not an environmental benefit of recycling metals?

options.label: a
options.text: It requires less energy than extracting from an ore

options.label: b
options.text: It reduces the amount of landfill

options.label: c
options.text: It reduces the cost of the metal

options.label: d
options.text: Less metal ore needs to be taken from the ground

questions.question: Why is it cheaper to recycle metals than to extract them from their ore?

options.label: a
options.text: It can be done closer to where the metals are thrown away

options.label: b
options.text: Transporting scrap metal is cheaper than transporting the ore

options.label: c
options.text: The people who do the recycling are paid less than people who extract metals from the ores

options.label: d
options.text: There are far less processes involved in recycling than in extracting metal from an ore

questions.question: When they reach the place they are to be recycled, how is recycling of metals carried out?

options.label: a
options.text: Metals are added to their molten ore

options.label: b
options.text: Metals are taken from pieces of waste recovered from spoil heaps

options.label: c
options.text: Metals are reduced using carbon and moulded into ingots

options.label: d
options.text: Metals are melted down and reshaped

questions.question: Why is extracting iron from its ore so expensive compared to recycling it?

options.label: a
options.text: Iron ore has to be mined

options.label: b
options.text: The iron ore needs to be purified

options.label: c
options.text: Extraction requires chemical reactions to be carried out

questions.question: Apart from the costs associated with preparing the ore, which of the following is likely to make extracting aluminium expensive?

options.label: a
options.text: The cost of the staff needed to work in the factory

options.label: b
options.text: The cost of the electricity used during the electrolysis of the aluminium ore

options.label: c
options.text: The cost of the carbon required to displace the aluminium from its ore

options.label: d
options.text: The cost of casting the aluminium into ingots

questions.question: Why is aluminium easy to recycle?

options.label: c
options.text: It is mainly made into drinks cans

options.label: d
options.text: It has a relatively low melting point for a metal

questions.question: Titanium is also an expensive metal. Only a small portion is ever recycled. Which of the following reasons is the most likely explanation?

options.label: a
options.text: It is usually used in small quantities to make alloys rather than using it on its own

options.label: b
options.text: It is only used to make small items and it is not worth it

options.label: c
options.text: It is a heavy metal and the cost of transporting it for recycling is too expensive

questions.question: Which of the following environmental issues could recycling metals reduce?

Read the following information and then decide which of the four answers contains the missing words in the correct order.

Before any metals can be ________ the scrap metal has to be collected, ____________ and sorted, which all cost money. The main problem with recycling metals is ____________ the useful metal from the rest of the rubbish. In domestic recycling plants iron and steel objects can be picked out using an __________ as most other materials are non-magnetic.
Why is the recycling of copper becoming more and more important?

options.label: a
options.text: The world's reserves of high grade copper ores are very limited and could be exhausted within a few human generations

options.text: Many copper manufacturers have gone out of business so not much is being made

options.text: New laws have made copper ore mining much more difficult

options.label: c
options.text: Tungsten has a high melting point

questions.question: House electrical systems require a good earthing system to make them safe. The earthing system carries electricity safely into the ground and causes the safety devices in the house to 'trip', preventing electric shocks. Electricians sometimes fix the earth wires of a domestic electrical system to copper pipes used for the plumbing. Why is this?

options.label: a
options.text: The water in the pipe conducts electricity to earth

options.label: b
options.text: Copper is a good conductor of electricity

options.label: c
options.text: The pipes will stay cool in the event of an electrical emergency

options.label: d
options.text: It is an easy thing to do and saves them the time and trouble of putting a proper system in place

questions.question: Why do metals conduct electricity?

options.label: d
options.text: The layers of ions in a metal

questions.question: Why can metals be bent and pulled into shape?

options.label: a
options.text: The atoms of metals are soft

options.label: b
options.text: The layers of metal ions are able to slide over and past each other

options.label: c
options.text: The ions of a metal are able to break free of each other

questions.question: Why is burning  biofuels less of a problem than burning fossil fuels?

options.label: a
options.text: They don't produce any CO2 when they burn

options.label: b
options.text: They are renewable and don't release carbon locked away millions of years ago

options.label: c
options.text: They are cheaper and easier to produce when compared to fossil fuels

questions.question: Which one of the following could be an ethical argument against growing plants for biofuels?

options.label: b
options.text: You need a lot more people to produce biofuels than fossil fuels

options.label: c
options.text: It could make fuel prices lower

options.label: d
options.text: It could increase food prices or cause food shortages

questions.question: Which impurity in fuels causes acid rain when it burns?
Which of the following is a balanced equation that shows how sulfur dioxide is formed?
Apart from sulfur, what else from burning fuels is a major contributor to acid rain?
Which of the following might be directly caused by burning fuels?
Which of the following products of burning fuels could be responsible for global dimming?
One of the pollutants from burning fossil fuels is carbon dioxide. To which of the following environmental issues does it contribute?

options.label: a
options.text: The hole in the ozone layer

questions.question: What are biofuels?

options.label: c
options.text: Fuels made from any living thing or its waste

options.label: d
options.text: Fuels made only from animal dung

questions.question: Why is carbon dioxide from fossil fuels a particular issue?

options.label: b
options.text: It is more polluting than the carbon dioxide breathed out by animals

options.label: d
options.text: It was locked away millions of years ago and so is adding to that which is present in the air today

Which of the following products of burning fuels could be responsible for global dimming?
During the cracking of alkanes from crude oil, one of the products is:
What is the key difference between the alkanes and the alkenes that are produced by cracking, and what is the cause?

options.label: a
options.text: Alkenes are much more reactive as they are unsaturated

options.label: b
options.text: Alkanes are much more reactive as they are suturated

options.label: c
options.text: Alkenes have a smell because their chemical bonds are weak

options.label: d
options.text: Alkenes are all coloured compounds because they polarise the light passing through them

questions.question: What is the general formula for any alkene?
What is the test used to detect an alkene and what is the result?
Which of the following represents a carbon to carbon double bond in an alkene?
Ethanol can be added to petrol used in car engines. Why is this?

options.label: b
options.text: It is a good way of getting rid of the ethanol that we don't need

options.label: c
options.text: It makes the fuel easier to burn than just using petrol on its own

options.label: d
options.text: It burns more cleanly, reducing air pollution

questions.question: Ethanol can be made by fermenting plants or from the ethene obtained by cracking crude oil. What would be a disadvantage of making it from oil?

options.label: a
options.text: It comes from a renewable source

options.label: b
options.text: It comes from a non-renewable source

options.label: d
options.text: It doesn't mix as easily with petrol as the ethanol from plants

questions.question: Which of the fractions of oil is most often used to manufacture chemicals instead of being used as a fuel?
Why is the residue fraction often used for cracking?

options.label: a
options.text: It is too sticky to use for anything else

options.label: c
options.text: It is the cheapest thing to do with it

options.label: d
options.text: There is more produced than is used

questions.question:
Read the following passage. Which answer gives the missing words in the correct order?

There are two good reasons for cracking oil __________. Firstly, there just aren't enough fuels like petrol or _________ in the original crude oil to meet demand. questions.question:
Read the following passage. Which answer gives the missing words in the correct order?

There are two good reasons for cracking oil __________. Firstly, there just aren't enough fuels like petrol or _________ in the original crude oil to meet demand. Secondly, _______ that are needed to manufacture other chemicals are not found in oil but can be made from it. Cracking means the vast majority of crude oil can be turned into useful products and not just burnt as ______.
Which of the following statements best describes the molecules in crude oil?

options.label: a
options.text: The molecules in crude oil are not chemically combined

options.label: b
options.text: The molecules in crude oil are chemically combined

options.label: c
options.text: The molecules in crude oil are all very large

options.label: d
options.text: The molecules in crude oil are all very small

questions.question: Why does fractional distillation of crude oil work?

options.label: a
options.text: Because the chemicals in crude oil have the same melting points

options.label: b
options.text: Because the chemicals in crude oil boil at different temperatures

options.label: c
options.text: Because the chemicals in crude oil have different viscosities

options.label: d
options.text: Because the chemicals in crude oil are very volatile

questions.question: Crude oil is put into the fractionating column in what form?
Where are the coolest temperatures in the fractionating column?
What happens to the chemicals in the crude oil vapour as they rise?

options.label: b
options.text: As they reach an area that is the same temperature as their boiling point they condense

options.label: c
options.text: As they reach an area that is the same temperature as their melting point they condense

options.label: d
options.text: They react together to form fuels

questions.question: At an oil refinery, how often is oil put into the fractional distillation column?
Most of the fractions of crude oil are used as what?
The chemicals from crude oil are mainly alkanes. Which of the following statements best describes alkanes?

options.label: a
options.text: Alkanes are hydrocarbons with sulfur molecules attached

options.label: b
options.text: Alkanes are hydrocarbons with multiple bonds between the carbon atoms

options.label: c
options.text: Alkanes are hydrocarbons with single bonds between the carbon atoms

options.label: d
options.text: Alkanes are hydrocarbons made from carbon atoms alternating with hydrogen and oxygen atoms in a long chain

questions.question: The demand for certain fractions of oil is greater or smaller than the output, for example, there is not enough of the fraction containing the chemicals used as fuel for cars, and there is more of the bitumen fraction than can be used. How is this problem solved?

options.label: a
options.text: Some of the gas molecules are joined together to make bigger molecules like petrol and diesel

options.label: b
options.text: More roads are built to use up the bitumen fraction

options.label: c
options.text: Some of the molecules in the bitumen fraction are cracked

options.label: d
options.text: More oil is distilled so that enough of each fraction is made, the unused products are then thrown away

questions.question: Which of the following is not required for cracking?
Cracking fractions of crude oil produces smaller alkane molecules and alkenes. Which of the following is not an alkene?
Why are alkenes so useful as monomers?

options.label: a
options.text: Because alkenes contain only double bonds

options.label: b
options.text: Because alkenes contain only single bonds

options.label: c
options.text: Because alkenes contain at least one oxygen atom

options.label: d
options.text: Because alkenes contain at least one double bond between carbon atoms

questions.question: How is a double bond represented?
How are polymers made from alkenes?

options.label: a
options.text: Polymers are one of the main products made by cracking crude oil

options.label: b
options.text: Polymers are made by adding lots of smaller molecules together in a long chain

options.label: c
options.text: Polymers are made by carrying out ordinary distillation on crude oil instead of fractional distillation

options.label: d
options.text: Polymers are made by using enzymes

questions.question: What do scientists call the small molecules that are joined together to make polymers?
What monomer is used to make poly(propene)?
Which of the following is a use for polymers?
Which of the following is not an advantage of polymers?

options.label: d
options.text: Colour can be built into a polymer when it is made

questions.question: How are scientists trying to make products made with polymers biodegradeable?

options.label: a
options.text: They are developing ways of chemically treating plastics as they go into landfill sites

options.label: b
options.text: They are developing methods of burning plastics that don't pollute the air

options.label: c
options.text: There is nothing that can be done to solve the problem

options.label: d
options.text: They are developing plastics that contain cornstarch as well as polymers

questions.question: What is the most environmentally friendly way to dispose of your used plastic items?
What are the two methods of extracting vegetable oils?
Which parts of a plant are usually used as the source of vegetable oils?
Why does food cook faster in vegetable oils than in boiling water?

options.label: a
options.text: The water gets into the food, slowing down the cooking

options.label: b
options.text: Oil is a chemical and chemicals cook things faster than just water can

options.label: c
options.text: They have higher boiling points than water

questions.question: Why do foods cooked in vegetable oils usually contain more energy than foods cooked by other methods?

options.label: a
options.text: They have been subjected to higher temperatures and food holds on to the extra energy

options.label: b
options.text: Some of the oil remains on and in the food

options.label: c
options.text: They pick up energy from the other foods they are cooked with more easily in the oil

options.label: d
options.text: They don't cool off as quickly

questions.question: Why is eating a diet mainly of food cooked in vegetable oils unhealthy?

options.label: b
options.text: You can only cook foods that are already high in calories in oils

options.label: c
options.text: The high temperatures used for cooking destroy any nutrients in the food

options.label: d
options.text: The extra calories can make you overweight

questions.question: What chemical is needed to turn vegetable oil into margarine?
Oils and fats can be termed saturated or unsaturated. Unsaturated means what?

options.label: a
options.text: All of the water has been removed dusring processing

options.label: c
options.text: There are no carbon to carbon double bonds in the molecule

options.label: d
options.text: There is at least one carbon to carbon double bond in the molecule

questions.question: What is an emulsion?

options.label: b
options.text: A mixture of oil and water

options.label: c
options.text: Something that is used for moisturising the skin

options.label: d
options.text: Something that is only used in cooking

questions.question: An emulsifier must be added to make an emulsion (such as paint, skin cream or mayonnaise) stable. Which of the following are the characteristics of a good emulsifier?

options.label: a
options.text: Does not form chemical bonds with oils, fats or water

options.label: b
options.text: Forms chemical bonds with oils and fats only

options.label: c
options.text: Forms chemical bonds with water only

options.label: d
options.text: Forms chemical bonds with oils and fats and water

questions.question: Unsaturated oils usually take what form at room temperature?

options.label: a
options.text: Unsaturated oils are solids at room temperature

options.label: b
options.text: Unsaturated oils are liquids at room temperature

options.label: c
options.text: Unsaturated oils are gases at room temperature

options.label: d
options.text: Unsaturated oils are emulsions at room temperature

questions.question: Why do foods cooked in vegetable oils usually contain more energy than foods cooked by other methods?

options.label: d

questions.question: Which of the layers of the Earth is the hottest?
What is thought to cause the plates to move around?
When seen in cross section, the core accounts for about how much of the Earth?
Alfred Wegener suggested that the continents moved around on the surface of the Earth. Which of the following is not one of the observations he used?

options.label: a
options.text: The same types of fossilised plants and animals are found in South America and Africa

options.label: b
options.text: Madagascar fits the east coast of Africa

options.label: c
options.text: Africa and South America fit together like pieces in a jigsaw puzzle

options.label: d
options.text: Matching rock formations and mountain chains are found in South America and Africa

questions.question: Wegener put forward his theory early in the twentieth century but scientists at the time refused to accept his idea until the 1960s. Why?

questions.question: Wegener used the similarities between fossil animals and plants as evidence for his theory. How did his critics explain it?

options.label: a
options.text: They were accidentally transported round the world on ships

options.label: b
options.text: The animals swam and plant seeds were blown on the wind

options.label: c
options.text: There were once land bridges linking the continents

options.label: d
options.text: It was a mistake and the fossil animals and plants were not actually the same

questions.question: What was the main piece of evidence that convinced scientists that continental drift was right?

options.label: a
options.text: They discovered that the land bridges didn't exist

options.label: b
options.text: They measured the distance between America and Britain and found it was further than the last time they measured

options.label: c
options.text: They used sensitive equipment buried in the ground to observe the movement of the plates

options.label: d
options.text: Evidence from magnetism in the ocean floor showed that the seafloors were spreading by a few centimetres each year

Argon is a noble gas and is inert (does not react with other substances). For that reason it is used in light bulbs but how is it obtained from the air?

options.label: a
options.text: The air is solidified and argon is collected as the solid air sublimes

options.label: b
options.text: The air is liquified and argon can be collected by fractional distillation

options.label: c
options.text: It can be filtered out from the air by using a special filter

options.label: d
options.text: It is made from other chemicals

questions.question: Why is nitrogen used in food packaging?

options.label: a
options.text: It makes the food lighter and easier to transport

options.label: b
options.text: It is cheaper than using all of the air

options.label: c
options.text: It makes food taste a lot better

options.label: d
options.text: It is unreactive and helps to keep the food fresher

questions.question: What natural process is thought to have created the early atmosphere and which was the main gas?

options.label: a
options.text: Volcanic action created the early atmosphere and carbon dioxide was the main gas

options.label: b
options.text: Photosynthesis created the early atmosphere and oxygen was the main gas

options.label: c
options.text: Cosmic rays created the early atmosphere and nitrogen was the main gas

options.label: d
options.text: Global warming created the early atmosphere and carbon dioxide was the main gas

questions.question: The first green algae-like plants evolved about 2,000 million years ago. How would this have affected the early atmosphere?

options.label: a
options.text: It reduced the carbon dioxide levels and increased the amount of oxygen

options.label: b
options.text: It started to fix nitrogen into the soil

options.label: c
options.text: It converted methane into ammonia which was then converted to oxygen by animals

options.label: d
options.text: It would not have caused any changes to the early atmosphere

questions.question: What may have happened to the rest of the carbon dioxide from the early atmosphere?

options.label: a
options.text: It has been lost into space

options.label: b
options.text: It has been changed into other gases by radiation from the Sun

options.label: c
options.text: It was absorbed by the oceans and then has been locked into rocks like limestone

options.label: d
options.text: It has been absorbed by lava from volcanoes

questions.question: The level of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere has remained almost the same for 200 million years. Since the start of the twentieth century it has increased dramatically. What is thought to have caused this?
