options.text: Covering the liquid with a beaker

options.label: b
options.text: Making sure that there were no draughts

options.label: c
options.text: Spreading it out over a larger area

questions.question: What happens to a gas in a sealed container when it is heated?

options.label: b
options.text: The pressure of the gas increases

questions.question: Some types of thermometer are filled with mercury, a liquid metal. Why do they work?

options.label: a
options.text: Mercury is a metal so it conducts heat into the thermometer

options.label: b
options.text: Mercury behaves in an unusual way

options.label: c
options.text: Particles of liquids expand when they are heated and contract when they are cooled so the mercury fills more or less of the thermometer depending on the temperature

options.label: d
options.text: The particles move faster or slower depending on the temperature so the mercury expands and contracts

questions.question: According to the kinetic theory, what are the particles in a heated solid doing?

options.label: a
options.text: Vibrating more slowly than when the solid was cool

options.label: b
options.text: Vibrating more rapidly than when the solid was cool

options.label: c
options.text: Moving around more slowly than when the solid was cool

options.label: d
options.text: Moving around more rapidly than when the solid was cool

questions.question: What will a substance do when it is heated?
Why does hot air rise?

options.label: b
options.text: It is pushed there by the cold air

options.label: c
options.text: It is less dense than colder air

options.label: d
options.text: It doesn't, this is a myth

questions.question: Why are warm fluids less dense than their cold equivalent?

options.label: a
options.text: Some of the fluid escapes from the particles so they are lighter

options.label: c
options.text: Hot particles lose their quarks and become lighter

questions.question: Which states of matter contract when you cool them?
What happens to the particles of water vapour as it changes from a gas into a liquid to form a film of water on the inside surface of a cold window?

options.label: a
options.text: When the particles of the water vapour hit the window, they stick to it

options.label: b
options.text: The particles lose energy to the cold surface, slow down and become closer together

options.label: c
options.text: The particles clump together because of the light coming through the window, forming water

options.label: d
options.text: The particles speed up, forming water droplets

questions.question: When a liquid is evaporating it cools down. Why?

options.label: a
options.text: The faster particles escape leaving the slower particles behind

options.label: c
options.text: Evaporation needs a breeze and breezes cool things down

options.label: d
options.text: It has a smaller volume than before

options.label: a
options.text: Covering the liquid with a beaker

options.label: b
options.text: Making sure that there were no draughts

options.label: c
options.text: Spreading it out over a larger area

options.label: b
options.text: The pressure of the gas increases

options.label: a
options.text: Mercury is a metal so it conducts heat into the thermometer

options.label: b
options.text: Mercury behaves in an unusual way

options.label: c
options.text: Particles of liquids expand when they are heated and contract when they are cooled so the mercury fills more or less of the thermometer depending on the temperature

options.label: d
options.text: The particles move faster or slower depending on the temperature so the mercury expands and contracts

questions.question: In which direction does thermal energy (heat) flow?

options.label: d
options.text: It depends on the exact situation

questions.question: The rate at which an object transfers thermal energy depends on what?

options.label: b
options.text: Its volume and what it is made from

options.label: c
options.text: The nature of the surface with which it is in contact

questions.question:
A student investigated the rate of heat transfer from four identical containers of water. The water was heated to different temperatures (shown below) and she noted the temperature drop during the first two minutes of cooling. Which answer puts them in the correct order, from lowest rate to highest rate?

Container A: 35oC
Container B: 55oC
Container C: 45oC
Container D: 80oC

A student investigated the rate of heat transfer from four identical containers of water. The water was heated to different temperatures (shown below). She then placed containers B and C in a freezer at -5oC and containers A and D in a room with a temperature of 20oC, and noted the temperature drop during the first two minutes of cooling. Which of the following statements is correct?
Container A: 35oC
Container B: 55oC
Container C: 45oC
Container D: 80oC

options.label: b
options.text: Container B and container D cooled at the same rate

options.label: d
options.text: Container B and container C cooled faster than all of the others

questions.question: At the back of a refigerator there is a condenser which is designed to change the hot refrigerant gas into a liquid. The tubes of the condenser are attached to hundreds of small metal 'fins'. Why?

options.label: a
options.text: To make the process of condensation work more efficiently

options.label: b
options.text: To make the refrigerator look good

options.label: c
options.text: For insulation so that the food inside stays cold

questions.question: Why are cooling fins thin and flat?

options.label: a
options.text: To give them a small surface area

options.label: b
options.text: To make them as light as possible

options.label: c
options.text: To make them fit into place better

options.label: d
options.text: To give them a large surface area compared to their volume

questions.question: Based on the information that "the chemical called ether evaporates much faster than water", which of the following statements is true?

options.label: a
options.text: Ether must be a colourless liquid

options.label: b
options.text: Ether must be a colourless solid

options.label: c
options.text: Ether will make a surface cooler than water would

options.label: d
options.text: Water will make a surface cooler than ether would

questions.question: During the winter, moisture often condenses on the inside of windows of old houses. This rarely happens during the summer. Which of the following is likely to be the main reason for this?

options.label: a
options.text: There are no plants actively growing in the winter to absorb the moisture for photosynthesis

options.label: b
options.text: The glass of the window is colder in the winter than it is in the summer

options.label: c
options.text: Central heating systems used in winter give off moisture

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false?

options.label: a
options.text: Conduction involves thermal energy being passed between vibrating particles

options.label: b
options.text: Solids are better heat conductors than liquids and gases

options.label: c
options.text: Plastic is a good insulator because it contains free electrons

options.label: d
options.text: When a liquid is evaporating it cools down

questions.question: During the cold weather, birds can often appear bigger than they do when the weather is warm. Which of the following is the most likely explanation?

options.label: a
options.text: Muscles in their skin lift their feathers further away from their body than in the summer

options.label: b
options.text: People put out food for the birds so they eat more

options.label: c
options.text: They do it to try to attract a mate

options.label: d
options.text: There are no leaves on the trees so they just look bigger when really they are the same size

questions.question: In which direction does thermal energy (heat) flow?

options.label: d
options.text: It depends on the exact situation

questions.question: The rate at which an object transfers thermal energy depends on what?

options.label: b
options.text: Its volume and what it is made from

options.label: c
options.text: The nature of the surface with which it is in contact

questions.question:
A student investigated the rate of heat transfer from four identical containers of water. The water was heated to different temperatures (shown below) and she noted the temperature drop during the first two minutes of cooling. Which answer puts them in the correct order, from lowest rate to highest rate?

Container A: 35oC
Container B: 55oC
Container C: 45oC
Container D: 80oC

A student investigated the rate of heat transfer from four identical containers of water. The water was heated to different temperatures (shown below). She then placed containers B and C in a freezer at -5oC and containers A and D in a room with a temperature of 20oC, and noted the temperature drop during the first two minutes of cooling. Which of the following statements is correct?
Container A: 35oC
Container B: 55oC
Container C: 45oC
Container D: 80oC

options.label: b
options.text: Container B and container D cooled at the same rate

options.label: d
options.text: Container B and container C cooled faster than all of the others

questions.question: As a train travels along its rails, its wheels create sparks. Apart from this light energy, what other forms of energy are wasted?
What is a Sankey diagram?

options.label: a
options.text: A diagram of the London Underground railway system

options.label: b
options.text: A diagram drawn to scale (usually using squared paper) to represent the efficiency of an energy transfer

options.label: c
options.text: A circuit diagram for a machine that can be used for measuring the efficiency of energy transfers

options.label: d
options.text: A graph showing only the percentage of useful energy produced in an energy transfer

questions.question: How is the efficiency of an energy transfer expressed?
If a filament light bulb consumes 150 J/s and produces 12 J/s of light energy, what is its efficiency?
A houseowner replaces their filament light bulbs with LED lighting. This is 85% efficient and requires only a 7 watt input. What is the useful power output of the new lights?
When the outside temperature is cold, the air inside a car is warmed by some of the thermal energy from the engine. What effect does this have on the overall efficiency of the car engine?

options.label: d
options.text: A Sankey diagram is needed to work it out

questions.question: What is the efficiency of a computer that consumes 25 J/s of electrical energy and wastes 9 J/s of heat energy?
Burning 2kg of wood in a particular woodburning stove releases 29 MJ of heat energy. If 25 MJ of that heat is transferred to the room, which of the following statements is true?

options.label: b
options.text: The fire is between 90% and 100% efficient

options.label: c
options.text: The fire is between 85% and 90% efficient

options.label: d
options.text: The efficiency of the fire is less than 85%

questions.question:
Distributing electrical energy through the 400,000 V cables of the National Grid wastes some of the energy of the electricity (see below). What is the efficiency of this part of the system to the nearest whole number? 

Total power generated: 62,161.5 MW
Step-up transformer losses: 157 MW 
Step-down transformer losses: 142 MW
Losses caused by heating of the cables during transmission: 1.4%

A roof receives 1,000 W/m2 of energy from the Sun on a clear, sunny day. How many watts would be produced from a 5cm wide by 20cm long solar cell positioned on the roof if the efficiency of the solar cell is 14%?

In what substances can convection occur?
What is the main way that heat passes through a brick in the wall of a building?
How does extra heat affect the particles of a metal?

options.label: b
options.text: It makes them move around more and change places, reducing its density

options.label: c
options.text: It slows down the movement of the particles

questions.question: Why are metals good heat conductors?

options.label: c
options.text: Their particles are packed close together

questions.question: Houses built with thick stone walls usually stay cooler inside during the summer than houses built with thinner brick walls. Why might this be?

options.label: a
options.text: Conduction is slower through the thicker walls

options.label: b
options.text: No convection can occur through the thicker walls

options.label: c
options.text: No conduction can occur through the thicker walls

options.label: d
options.text: The clay used to make bricks always contains some impurities that make it a better conductor of heat than stone

questions.question: Which state(s) of matter is (or are) fluids?

"Particles with more energy move in to take the place of particles with less energy"
What method of heat transfer is being described in the previous sentence?
Thunderstorms are created by which form(s) of energy transfer in the atmosphere?
On a sunny day, why is it slightly harder to swim back to the shore of a lake than to swim towards the centre?

options.label: a
options.text: The sun makes the water at the edge of the lake expand more than at the centre so you are swimming uphill

options.label: b
options.text: The sun heats shallow water at the edge faster than the deep water, creating a convection current that flows towards the centre

options.label: c
options.text: You are more tired because you have already swum out to the centre of the lake

questions.question: Why do hot air ballons rise?

options.label: a
options.text: The flames from the burner are going upwards and they push the balloon into the air

options.label: b
options.text: The helium they contain is lighter than air

options.label: c
options.text: The heat from the burners causes the air inside to become less dense

options.label: d
options.text: They only rise because the pilot throws out some weight from the basket

questions.question: Which of the following features of a vacuum flask is designed to reduce the rate of heat transfer by radiation?
Which of the features of a vacuum flask is designed to slow down the rate of heat transfer by reducing both conduction and convection?
The smallest fox in the world, the fennec fox, lives in the Sahara desert. It has very large ears. How do its ears help it to keep cool?

options.label: a
options.text: They can be flapped backwards and forwards creating a cool breeze over the fox

options.label: b
options.text: The fox can twist and bend its ears to shade itself from the Sun

options.label: c
options.text: They have a large surface area

questions.question: A cool box is used to keep food cooler than the surroundings. They are often used to carry chilled or frozen food home from a supermarket or to keep food fresh at a picnic. Which of the following materials would be suitable to make the walls of a cool box?

options.label: d
options.text: Polyurethane foam (a type of plastic that contains air bubbles)

questions.question: 18,000 J of energy was transferred from an electric heater to a 2kg block of steel. The temperature increased by 18oC. Based on these figures, what is the specific heat capacity of the steel?
If 18,000 J of energy was transferred from an electric heater over the course of 2 minutes, what is the rate that heat was transferred?

LEDs are low energy alternatives to conventional light bulbs but they still generate a lot of heat when they are switched on. They need to be attached to a heat sink to keep them cool. Which of the following would make a good heat sink for an LED?

A group of students carried out an investigation into the rate at which different foods cool down. They measured the temperature of each food at 30 second intervals until the food had cooled from 80oC to room temperature. They then drew graphs of the results. In each case, the graph was the same shape. Which of the following describes the shape of their graphs?

options.label: a
options.text: A linear graph with a negative gradient

options.label: b
options.text: A lineear graph with a positive gradient

options.label: c
options.text: A curved line graph with a negative gradient that is steeper at higher temperatures

options.label: d
options.text: A curved line graph with a positive gradient that was steeper at lower temperatures

questions.question: Which of the following would be the worst conductor of heat?
Which way does thermal energy travel?

options.label: c
options.text: From a conductor of heat to a non conductor

options.label: d
options.text: It varies depending on the situation

questions.question: Which of the following features of a vacuum flask is designed to reduce the rate of heat transfer by radiation?
Which of the features of a vacuum flask is designed to slow down the rate of heat transfer by reducing both conduction and convection?
The smallest fox in the world, the fennec fox, lives in the Sahara desert. It has very large ears. How do its ears help it to keep cool?

options.label: a
options.text: They can be flapped backwards and forwards creating a cool breeze over the fox

options.label: b
options.text: The fox can twist and bend its ears to shade itself from the Sun

options.label: c
options.text: They have a large surface area

questions.question: A cool box is used to keep food cooler than the surroundings. They are often used to carry chilled or frozen food home from a supermarket or to keep food fresh at a picnic. Which of the following materials would be suitable to make the walls of a cool box?

options.label: d
options.text: Polyurethane foam (a type of plastic that contains air bubbles)

questions.question: Thermal radiation can only travel through which substances?
Which one of the following emits the most infrared radiation?
Which are the best emitters of thermal radiation?

Put the following in order of best to worst reflectors of infrared radiation:

1. Red, dull
2. White, shiny
3. Black, dull
4. Red, shiny
In sunny countries, houses are often painted white. Why?

options.label: a
options.text: Painting them white lowers the U-value of the walls

options.label: b
options.text: White paint does not conduct heat

options.label: c
options.text: White is a good reflector of thermal radiation

options.label: d
options.text: The white paint reflects the light into the narrow streets which otherwise would be dark

questions.question: Why are car radiators often painted matt black?

options.label: a
options.text: So that splashes of engine oil won't show up

options.label: c
options.text: To make the car more attractive to buyers

questions.question: In an electric toaster, what methods of heat transfer cook the bread?

options.label: d
options.text: Mainly convection but conduction has a part to play too

questions.question: Thermal radiation travels at what speed?
Which of the following does not use infrared radiation?

options.label: c
options.text: A remote control for a TV

questions.question: The inside container of a vacuum flask is silvered. Why?

options.label: a
options.text: To reduce heat loss by radiation

options.label: b
options.text: To completely prevent heat loss by radiation

options.label: c
options.text: To reduce heat loss by evaporation

options.label: d
options.text: To reduce heat loss by condensation

questions.question: What are U-values?

options.label: a
options.text: A measure of the thickness of an insulator

options.label: b
options.text: A measure of the temperature of an insulator

options.label: c
options.text: A measure of how fast heat can pass through an insulator

options.label: d
options.text: A measure of the surface area of an insulator

questions.question: The best insulators have what sort of U-value?
Which of the following is not a good reason for having solar hot water panels fitted?

options.label: a
options.text: They do not release any gases into the air as they heat the water

options.label: b
options.text: They reduce the bill for heating and hot water

options.label: c
options.text: On cloudy days, the water is not very hot

questions.question: How do solar hot water panels work?

options.label: a
options.text: Heat radiation from the sun warms the water which is then pumped to a storage tank

options.label: b
options.text: The light from the Sun is used to generate electricity that powers a water heater

options.label: c
options.text: They absorb heat from the air

options.label: d
options.text: They use heat escaping through the roof from inside the house to heat the water

questions.question: What is meant by payback time in the context of insulating a building?

options.label: a
options.text: The time taken to pay off any loans that you needed

options.label: b
options.text: How long it takes you to get your revenge on the builder after they have done a poor job

options.label: c
options.text: How long it takes to get a grant from the government for the insulation work

options.label: d
options.text: A measure of how cost-effective the insulation is

questions.question: If it costs 2,000 to insulate the walls and roof of a house, how long will the payback time be if it saves 250 per year?

During the day, the Sun transfers energy to an outdoor swimming pool. The mass of water in the pool is 5,000 kg. The specific heat capacity of water is 4,200 J/kg C. How much energy needs to be supplied to increase the water temperature by 5oC?

At night, a storage heater transfers electrical energy into thermal energy which is stored. During the day, the heat is released to warm the room. Which of the following would store the most thermal energy per kg?

To heat the water in a domestic hot water storage tank from 42C to 50C, an immersion heater transfers 4,536 kJ of energy to the water. How much water is in the tank? The specific heat capacity of water is 4,200 J/kgoC

A homeowner has part of the outside brick wall of her house demolished and fits double-glazed glass doors in the gap. The U-value of the wall was 0.4 and the U-value of glass doors is 1.8. What does this mean?

options.label: a
options.text: Her house is now better insulated

options.label: b
options.text: She will save money on heating bills

options.label: c
options.text: More heat will be lost from the house

options.label: d
options.text: There will be no change to the amount of heat lost from the house

questions.question: Substances with a low specific heat capacity can store how much thermal energy?

options.label: a
options.text: They can not store any thermal energy

options.label: b
options.text: They can store some thermal energy

options.label: c
options.text: They can store a lot of themal energy

options.label: d
options.text: They can store an unlimited amount of thermal energy

questions.question: As well as the specific heat capacity, what else affects the amount of thermal energy a material can store?

options.label: a
options.text: Nothing - it's just the specific heat capacity that matters

questions.question: What symbol is used to represent the specific heat capacity of a material?
What are the units of specific heat capacity?

In a laboratory experiment, a group of students used a copper block with a hole drilled in for a thermometer and a second hole in for the heater. Which of the following is not required to calculate the specific heat capacity?

options.label: a
options.text: Joulemeter reading at the start and end

options.label: d
options.text: Mass in kg of the copper block

questions.question: The specific heat capacity of water is 4,200 J/kgoC. The specific heat capacity of mineral oil is 2,100 J/kgoC. Based on this information, which statement is correct?

options.label: a
options.text: Mineral oil would be of little use for storing heat

options.label: b
options.text: Water would be no use for storing heat

options.label: c
options.text: Kilogram for kilogram, mineral oil can absorb more thermal energy than water

options.label: d
options.text: Water can store more heat than the same mass of mineral oil

questions.question: How much energy must be transferred to raise the temperature of 2 kg of water from 27oC to 40oC? Water has a heat capacity of 4,200 J/kgoC

A homeowner uses a wood burning stove to heat his house. The casing of the stove gets hot when the wood inside is burning and is made from 120 kg of cast iron. It took 3,276 kJ of energy to raise the temperature of the stove casing from 18oC to 70oC. What is the specific heat capacity of the cast iron in J/kgoC?

When a particular car engine is working normally, 1.5 kg of coolant at a temperature of 114oC with a specific heat capacity of the of 3,800 J/kgoC passes through the radiator each second. If 91.2 kJ of energy is transferred to the surroundings, what is the temperature of the coolant leaving the radiator?
A block of copper was heated from 18oC to 33oC using 35 thousand joules of energy. The specific heat capacity of copper is 385  J/kgoC. What was the mass of the block of copper?

options.label: d
options.text: It can't be worked out without more information

questions.question: Energy can be transferred usefully, stored or dissipated, but cannot be created or destroyed. In the context of the above sentence, dissipated means what?

options.label: a
options.text: Energy is lost into the surroundings

options.label: b
options.text: Energy is lost into the ground

options.label: c
options.text: Energy  is lost into the air

questions.question: When energy has been dissipated, it:

options.label: b
options.text: can be recovered using a device called a heat pump

options.label: c
options.text: becomes spread out and less useful

questions.question: What are the two most common forms of waste energy?
What are the alternative names of the energy of movement, thermal energy and radiant energy which are all types of energy that are transferred from electrical energy by domestic appliances?

An air source heat pump is an electrically powered device that recovers heat energy from the air. For every kilowatt of electrical energy used, it provides three kilowatts of heat energy. Some homes are heated using a heat pump. Which of the following is not an advantage of using such an appliance when compared with the alternative of using a fossil fuel powered boiler?
Which of the following represents the energy transfers in a food mixer?

options.label: d
options.text: Electrical to kinetic, sound and heat

questions.question: Digital mp3 players have almost completely replaced portable CD players. When you compare the energy transfers, which of the following types of energy is found in one but not the other?
What is the energy transfer that an electric guitar is designed to make?
In developing countries, many homes do not yet have a source of mains electricity and need to rely on batteries. Batteries store which type of energy?
A wind-up radio was invented to help people living in communities where it is not always possible to buy batteries. Which of the following represent the main energy changes in such a device?

options.label: b
options.text: Gravitational potential to electrical and heat

options.label: c
options.text: Elastic potential to kinetic, electrical and sound

options.label: d
options.text: Gravitational potential to chemical, electrical and sound

Which of the following represents the energy transfers in a food mixer?

options.label: d
options.text: Electrical to kinetic, sound and heat

options.text: Elastic potential to kinetic, electrical and sound

options.label: d

questions.question: Which of the following is considered to be a disadvantage of producing electricity from water stored behind a dam?

options.label: a
options.text: Wildlife habitats and farmland are lost when the dam is built and the reservoir created

options.label: b
options.text: Electricity is only produced in rainy weather

options.label: c
options.text: Electricity has to be used to store the water

options.label: d
options.text: The dam creates pollution whilst it is being built

questions.question: Which of the following is not an advantage of tidal energy?

options.label: b
options.text: The tidal barrage could act as a bridge from one side of the estuary to the other

options.label: c
options.text: The tidal barrage could alter the ecosystems around the estuary

options.label: d
options.text: At very high tides the tidal barrage can be used to prevent flooding

questions.question: Geothermal energy is renewable because it uses what?

options.label: a
options.text: Warm winds that blow out from the Sahara Desert

options.label: b
options.text: It produces a lot of air pollution

options.label: d
options.text: It can only be used in a few places on the Earth

options.text: Wind turbines do not pollute the air when they are generating electricity and it is a renewable form of energy

options.label: b
options.text: The wind turbines emit (give off) dangerous microwave radiation when they are working

options.label: c
options.text: Compared to a power staton, they produce only small quantities of electricity but there are no fuel costs

options.label: d
options.text: Some people object to wind power because they feel the turbines are noisy and spoil the view

questions.question: What is a practical disadvantage of nearly all forms of wind, water and solar powered electricity generation?

options.text: They are noisy and look out of place in the environment

options.label: c
options.text: They need to be built at sea for safety reasons

options.label: d
options.text: They don't generate electricity all of the time

options.label: c
options.text: Solar cells are expensive and inefficient

options.label: d
options.text: Solar cells and solar panels both release greenhouse gases when they are working

questions.question: About seven to eight percent of the electrical energy is lost in the National Grid, mainly as which type of energy?
Why is electricity carried by the supergrid at very high voltage?

options.label: b
options.text: That is the voltage that power station generators produce

options.label: d
options.text: At lower voltages, it would not have the power to go all over the country

questions.question: The electricity generated at power stations is usually at 25,000 V. Which type of transformer is used to change the voltage required by the supergrid?
Where would you find a step-down transformer?

options.label: b
options.text: In an electricity substation near to the consumers

options.label: c
options.text: Part way along the power cables of the National Grid

questions.question: Which of the following is not an advantage of the National Grid?

options.label: a
options.text: Electricity is available at a standard voltage throughout Britain

options.label: b
options.text: If a power station breaks down, others can increase output to compensate

options.label: d
options.text: Sudden increased demands in electricity can be met

questions.question: Which of the following would be a good stand-by power station?

options.text: They use the heat to heat local buildings as well as to generate electricity

options.label: d
options.text: They are run by local businesses so they have to be more efficient to make them more profit

questions.question: When the National Grid was established, the cables were all carried by pylons. Now, some of the cables of the supergrid have been buried underground. Which of the following is not an advantage of buried high voltage cables?

options.label: b
options.text: Underground cables are less likely to be damaged or broken in bad weather

options.label: c
options.text: Underground cables are more expensive to install

options.label: d
options.text: Underground cables have lower maintenance costs

questions.question:
Which of the following contains the missing words from the passage in the correct order?

________ transformers are used at power stations to produce the very high ____________ needed to ensure that electricity is transmitted efficiently through the National Grid. Such high voltages are dangerous to use in the home, so _________ transformers are used in substations near to homes to reduce the voltage to safe levels. The voltage of ________ electricity is about 230 V.
The National Grid is a system of what?

options.label: b
options.text: A system of cables and transformers

options.label: c
options.text: A system of cables, transformers and power stations

options.label: d
options.text: A system of cables, transformers, power stations and consumers

questions.question: About seven to eight percent of the electrical energy is lost in the National Grid, mainly as which type of energy?
Why is electricity carried by the supergrid at very high voltage?

options.label: b
options.text: That is the voltage that power station generators produce

options.label: d
options.text: At lower voltages, it would not have the power to go all over the country

questions.question: The electricity generated at power stations is usually at 25,000 V. Which type of transformer is used to change the voltage required by the supergrid?
Where would you find a step-down transformer?

options.label: b
options.text: In an electricity substation near to the consumers

options.label: c
options.text: Part way along the power cables of the National Grid

questions.question: Which of the following is not an advantage of the National Grid?

options.label: a
options.text: Electricity is available at a standard voltage throughout Britain

options.label: b
options.text: If a power station breaks down, others can increase output to compensate

options.label: d
options.text: Sudden increased demands in electricity can be met

questions.question: Which of the following would be a good stand-by power station?
Why are CHP (combined heat and power) stations more efficient than most fossil fuel burning power stations?

options.label: a
options.text: They use the heat to heat local buildings as well as to generate electricity

options.label: d
options.text: They are run by local businesses so they have to be more efficient to make them more profit

questions.question: When the National Grid was established, the cables were all carried by pylons. Now, some of the cables of the supergrid have been buried underground. Which of the following is not an advantage of buried high voltage cables?

options.label: b
options.text: Underground cables are less likely to be damaged or broken in bad weather

options.label: c
options.text: Underground cables are more expensive to install

options.label: d
options.text: Underground cables have lower maintenance costs

questions.question: A sound wave hits a brick wall at 36o from the normal. At what angle does it reflect?
On ray diagrams, what is the normal?

options.label: a

options.label: b
options.text: An imaginary line at 45o to the reflecting surface

options.label: c

options.label: d

questions.question: What is a virtual image?

options.label: a
options.text: An image that can be projected onto a screen

options.label: b
options.text: An image that can't be projected onto a screen

options.label: c
options.text: An image that is virtually perfect

options.label: d
options.text: An image of a person only

questions.question: The location of a virtual image in a plane mirror appears to be where?

options.label: c

options.label: d

questions.question: When you look at yourself in a mirror, your image is:
A hiker shouts to their friend and 4 seconds later hears an echo of their shout. If sound travels at 330 m/s, how far away was the cliff that reflected their shout?
Electromagnetic radiation travels in straight lines, so how come certain radio waves can be detected on the other side of the world without using artificial satellites?

options.label: a
options.text: Earth's gravity causes them to bend round

options.label: b
options.text: They reflect off a layer in the Earth's atmosphere

options.label: c
options.text: They can pass directly through the Earth

options.label: d
options.text: When they get to the edge of the atmosphere they are trapped by space

Which of the following statements about reflection is not true?

options.text: The angle of incidence is the same as the angle of reflection

options.label: c
options.text: The normal is drawn as a dotted or dashed line on ray diagrams

options.label: d
options.text: Rough surfaces scatter sound in all directions

options.text: X-rays cause electric and magnetic fields to vibrate at 90o to the direction they are travelling

questions.question: The distance from any point on one wave to the same point on the next wave is called what?
What is the amplitude of a transverse wave?

options.label: a
options.text: The height of the wave from the centre line to the crest

options.label: b
options.text: The height of the wave from the centre line to the trough

options.label: c
options.text: The maximum displacement of a wave

options.label: d
options.text: What is measured using a voltmeter and ammeter

questions.question: Which of these statements about the frequency of a transverse wave is true?

options.label: a
options.text: The frequency of a transverse wave is related to wavelength by the wave equation

options.label: b
options.text: The frequency of a transverse wave is measured in Hertz (Hz)

options.label: c
options.text: The frequency of a transverse wave is the number of waves passing a given point in 1 second

questions.question: As transverse seismic waves pass through the Earth, they must travel through several different layers. These layers have different densities. What happens to these waves when they reach a boundary between the layers?
When drawing a diagram to measure the angle of refraction, a student drew a broken (dashed) line at right angles to the boundary. What is the name of this line and which way would the wave refract?
Why do transverse waves refract when they enter a more dense medium?

options.label: c
options.text: They are deflected by the more dense particles

questions.question: Under what conditions does refraction not take place?

options.label: a
options.text: When the wave has a long wavelength

options.label: b
options.text: If the wave is travelling at less than the speed of light

options.label: c
options.text: If the angle of incidence is 90o

options.label: d
options.text: When the wave has already been refracted somewhere else

questions.question: When a transverse wave passes through a gap that is about the same width as its wavelength, which of the following is not true?

options.label: d
options.text: It can produce an interference pattern on a screen

The Apollo mission astronauts on the surface of the Moon needed radios to talk to each other, even when they were standing beside one another. Why?

options.label: a
options.text: Spacesuit material is too thick to hear through

options.label: b
options.text: There is no atmosphere on the Moon

options.label: c
options.text: The Moon is too noisy to allow a normal conversation

options.label: d
options.text: The Moon has less gravity than Earth

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true of an echo?

options.label: a
options.text: An echo is someone in the distance repeating what you say

options.label: b
options.text: An echo is only heard by the person who created it

options.label: c
options.text: An echo is as loud as the original sound

options.label: d
options.text: An echo is a sound wave that has been reflected

questions.question: A student looked up the speed of sound for several different media and noticed a pattern - it was fastest in solids and slowest in gases. Which of the following statements is the correct reason for this?

options.label: a
options.text: The particles of solids are denser than gases

options.label: b
options.text: The particles of solids are less dense than gases

options.label: c
options.text: The particles of solids are further apart than in gases

options.label: d
options.text: The particles of solids are closer together than in gases

questions.question: If you count the seconds between a flash of lightning and the rumble of thunder, then divide the time by three, you get the approximate distance in kilometers to the lightning. Why do you divide by three?

options.label: b
options.text: Sound travels three times faster than light

options.label: d
options.text: Light travels three times faster than sound

questions.question: Which of the following pieces of equipment is not required to see a sound wave?

options.label: a
options.text: The crests of the louder wave would be closer together

options.label: b
options.text: The crests of the louder wave would be taller

options.label: c
options.text: The crests of the louder wave would be further apart

options.label: d
options.text: The crests of the louder wave would be shorter

questions.question: Sound waves diffract. What does this mean?

options.label: a
options.text: As they pass an object or go through a gap that is approximately the same size or less than their wavelength, they spread out

options.text: As they pass an object or go through a gap that is considerably smaller than their wavelength, they spread out

options.label: c
options.text: As they pass an object or go through a gap that is much bigger than their wavelength, they spread out

options.label: d
options.text: As they pass an object or go through a gap that is approximately the same size as their wavelength, they come together and get louder

questions.question: Sound waves diffract. What does this mean?

options.label: a
options.text: As they pass an object or go through a gap that is approximately the same size or less than their wavelength, they spread out

options.label: b
options.text: As they pass an object or go through a gap that is considerably smaller than their wavelength, they spread out

options.label: c
options.text: As they pass an object or go through a gap that is much bigger than their wavelength, they spread out

options.label: d
options.text: As they pass an object or go through a gap that is approximately the same size as their wavelength, they come together and get louder

questions.question: As a sound wave passes, the particles of the medium are alternately compressed and uncompressed. Areas where the particles are not compressed are called what?
Wave frequency is measured in which unit?
A keyboard player plays a note of 440 Hz. What does this mean?

options.label: b
options.text: It cannot be heard by human ears

options.label: c
options.text: 440 waves reach the listener's ear each second

options.label: d
options.text: It has an amplitude of 440 cm

questions.question: If a wave of 440 Hz travels at 340 m/s, what is its wavelength?
What is the wavelength of the microwaves used by a mobile phone operator that uses microwaves with a frequency of 1.8 x 109 Hz and which travel at a speed of 3.0 x 108 m/s to transmit their signals?

options.label: c
options.text: Microwaves are the only waves that can travel through space

options.label: d
options.text: Other types of wave are not powerful enough to reach that far

options.label: d

questions.question: Which of the following waves can be changed by the Doppler effect?
When the source of a wave moves towards the observer, which of the following is not true?

options.label: a
options.text: The frequency of the waves is higher

options.label: b
options.text: If the wave is a light wave from a distant galaxy, the light is red-shifted

options.label: c
options.text: The wavelength of the waves is less

options.label: d
options.text: If the wave is a sound wave, the pitch sounds higher than it would if the source was stationary

questions.question: Galaxies emit (give out) many different types of wave. Which of the following would not be emitted by a galaxy?
Scientists measuring radio waves from a distant galaxy find the wavelength of  the waves they have detected is longer than it should be. What is this called?
Scientists discovered that all of the distant galaxies they looked at showed red-shift. What does that tell us about the direction that most galaxies are moving?

options.label: a
options.text: They are moving away from us

options.label: c
options.text: They are neither moving away nor towards us

options.label: d
options.text: Red-shift gives no information about how galaxies are moving

questions.question: What information does the red-shift of a galaxy give us?

options.label: a
options.text: Its distance and number of stars in the galaxy

options.label: b
options.text: Its speed and the number of stars it contains

options.label: c
options.text: Its weight and the speed it is moving away

options.label: d
options.text: Its distance and the speed of recession

questions.question: What conclusion can be drawn from the fact that nearly all galaxies are moving away from us?

options.label: a
options.text: Galaxies repel each other like magnets

options.label: b
options.text: The Universe is shaped like a hill and the galaxies are rolling down the hill

options.label: c
options.text: Galaxies all have the same electrical charge

questions.question: Which theory about the formation of the Universe is supported by its expansion?
In 1964, American radio astronomers Arno Penzias and Robert Wilson discovered the cosmic microwave background radiation (CMBR). Why was this an important discovery?

options.label: a
options.text: It proved beyond doubt that the Big Bang theory was completely correct

options.label: b
options.text: It proved that the Universe will never stop expanding

options.label: c
options.text: It provided good evidence to support the Big Bang theory

options.label: d
options.text: It completely disproved the Steady State theory

questions.question: As the Universe gets older, what might happen to the cosmic microwave background radiation?

options.label: d
options.text: It will turn into visible light
